\chapter*{Preface}

Thanks for choosing \sphinxstyleemphasis{Data Structures and Algorithms with Python}. This text was written based on classroom notes for two courses, an introductory data structures and algorithms course and an advanced data structures and algorithms course. The material contained in this text can be taught in two semesters. The early chapters in this text are intended as an introductory text for data structures and algorithms while later chapters cover advanced topics that are suitable for the advanced, second course in data structures and algorithms. The Python language is used throughout the text and some familiarity with Python or some other object\sphinxhyphen{}oriented language is assumed. However, the first chapter contains a Python primer for those coming from a different language background.

This text serves well as a follow\sphinxhyphen{}on text to \sphinxstyleemphasis{Python Programming Fundamentals} by Kent D. Lee and published by Springer, but does not require you to have read that text. In this text the next steps are taken to teach you how to handle large amounts of data efficiently. A number of algorithms are introduced and the need for them is motivated through examples that bring meaning to the problems we face as computer programmers. An algorithm is a well\sphinxhyphen{}defined procedure for accomplishing a task. Algorithms are an important part of Computer Science and this text explores many algorithms to give you the background you need when writing programs of your own. The goal is that having seen some of the sorts of algorithms presented in this text, you will be able to apply these techniques to other programs you write in the future.

Another goal of this text is to introduce you to the idea of computational complexity. While there are many unique and interesting algorithms that we could explore, it is important to understand that some algorithms are more efficient than others. While computers are very good at doing calculations quickly, an inefficient algorithm can make the fastest computer seem very slow or even make it appear to come to a halt. This text will show you what can and cannot be computed efficiently. The text builds this idea of efficiency from the most basic of facts giving you the tools you’ll need to determine just how efficient any algorithm is so you can make informed judgements about the programs you write.

The text assumes that you have some prior experience in computer programming, probably from an introductory programming course where you learned to break simple problems into steps that could be solved by a computer. The language you used may have been Python, but not necessarily. Python is an excellent language for a text on data structures and algorithms whether you have used it before or not. Python is an object\sphinxhyphen{}oriented programming language with operator overloading and dynamic typing. Whether this is your first exposure to Python or you used it in your first course, you’ll learn more about the language from this text. The first chapter of the text reviews some of the fundamentals of computer programming along with the basic syntax of Python to get you up to speed in the language. Then subsequent chapters dive into more advanced topics and should be read in sequence.

At the beginning of every chapter the goals of the chapter are stated. At the end of every chapter is a set of review questions that reinforce the goals of the chapter. These review questions are followed in each chapter by a few programming problems that relate to the chapter goals by asking you to use the things you learned in the chapter and apply them to a computer program. You can motivate your reading of a chapter by first consulting the review questions and then reading the chapter to answer them. Along the way, there are lots of examples to illustrate the concepts being introduced.

We hope you enjoy the text! If you have any questions or comments please send them to \sphinxhref{mailto:kentdlee@luther.edu}{kentdlee@luther.edu}.

\textendash{} Steve Hubbard and Kent D. Lee

\chapter*{For Teachers}



A typical introductory data structures course covers the first seven chapters of this text. Chapter 1 introduces Python programming and the Tkinter module which is used in various places in the text. Tkinter comes with Python, so no special libraries need be installed for students to use it. Tkinter is used to visualize many of the results in this text.

Chapter 2 introduces complexity analysis and depending on your needs, some of the material in chapter 2 could be skipped in an introductory data structures course. In particular, the material on \(\Theta\) notation and amortized complexity can be skipped. Big\sphinxhyphen{}Oh notation is enough for the first seven chapters. Typically chapter 7 is covered lightly and near the end of a semester course. It seems there is generally not enough time to cover graph theory in much detail.

Advanced courses in data structures and algorithms should start with chapter 1 if students are unfamiliar with Python or Tkinter. A brief refresher may not be bad even for those that have programmed using Python before. Chapter 2 should be covered in detail including the material on \(\Theta\) notation and amortized complexity.

Some review of hashing as it is used in sets and maps in chapter 5 may be good review earlier in the advanced course along with a brief discussion of binary search trees and tree traversals in chapter 6. Depending on your needs, chapter 7 would be a good chapter to cover next including the material on depth first search of a graph.

Chapter 8 is where the advanced material begins with assumptions made that students understand the concepts presented in the earlier chapters. The two introductory chapters along with chapters 8\sphinxhyphen{}12 make a seven chapter sequence that will fill a semeseter in an advanced course nicely.

This text is very project oriented. Solutions for all projects are available from Kent D. Lee. You can contact Kent at \sphinxhref{mailto:kentdlee@luther.edu}{kentdlee@luther.edu} for instructor solutions. You must provide proof (through a website or other reference) that you are an instructor at an educational institution to get access to the instructor materials.

If you have any suggestions or find any errors in the text, please let us know by emailing Kent at \sphinxhref{mailto:kentdlee@luther.edu}{kentdlee@luther.edu}. Thanks and we hope you enjoy using the text in your courses!
\begin{quote}

\textendash{}  Steve Hubbard and Kent D. Lee
\end{quote}




\chapter{Python Programming 101}
\label{\detokenize{chap1/chap1:python-programming-101}}\label{\detokenize{chap1/chap1::doc}}
This first chapter introduces Python to readers that have never programmed in Python before. It also provides instructions for installing Python on your computer. The Wing Integrated Development Environment (IDE) is recommended for students learning to program. Wing IDE 101 is the free version of the IDE for educational use. The chapter goes on to introduce classes, objects, and object\sphinxhyphen{}oriented programming by developing a drawing application using the Tkinter graphical user interface library.

An understanding of object\sphinxhyphen{}oriented programming concepts presented in this chapter is necessary before reading the rest of the text. The PyList datatype presented in this chapter is also used in subsequent chapters including chapter 2. Even if the reader has worked through an introductory text or has a basic understanding of Python, there are concepts from this first chapter that are used throughout the text.

\section{The Variable Length Records Draw Program}
\label{\detokenize{chap1/chap1:the-variable-length-records-draw-program}}

        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{newWindow}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}

            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} drawn. It also sets the sequence back to empty. It is necessary}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} for the graphicsCommands sequence to be in the object (i.e. }

            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} newWindow method returned.}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{clear}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{draw}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{p}{)}
            
        \PYG{n}{beginFillButton} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Button}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{sideBar}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{text} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Begin Fill}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{command}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{beginFillHandler}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Here is another event handler. This one handles mouse clicks on the screen.}
        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{clickHandler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:} 
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} When a mouse click occurs, get the widthSize entry value and set the width of the }
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} pen to the widthSize value. The int(widthSize.get()) is needed because}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} the width is an integer, but the entry widget stores it as a string.}
            \PYG{n}{cmd} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{GoToCommand}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{widthSize}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{penColor}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{draw}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{p}{)}          
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{listen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
           
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Here is how we tie the clickHandler to mouse clicks.}
        \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{onclick}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{clickHandler}\PYG{p}{)}  
        
        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{dragHandler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{cmd} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{GoToCommand}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{widthSize}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{penColor}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{draw}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{p}{)}  
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{listen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            
        \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ondrag}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{dragHandler}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} the undoHandler undoes the last command by removing it from the }
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} sequence and then redrawing the entire picture. }
        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{undoHandler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{removeLast}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{clear}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{penup}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pendown}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{cmd} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{p}{:}
                    \PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{draw}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{listen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                
        \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{onkeypress}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{undoHandler}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{u}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{listen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
   
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The main function in our GUI program is very simple. It creates the }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} root window. Then it creates the DrawingApplication frame which creates }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} all the widgets and has the logic for the event handlers. Calling mainloop}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} on the frames makes it start listening for events. The mainloop function will }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} return when the application is exited. }
\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{root} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Tk}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}  
    \PYG{n}{drawingApp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{DrawingApplication}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{root}\PYG{p}{)}  

    \PYG{n}{drawingApp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{mainloop}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Program Execution Completed.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
        
\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nv+vm}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}name\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}main\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{The Final XML Draw Program}
\label{\detokenize{chap1/chap1:the-final-xml-draw-program}}
You can download the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{final draw program with XML support}} from Appendix H of the text by clicking this link.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The imports include turtle graphics and tkinter modules. }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The colorchooser and filedialog modules let the user}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} pick a color and a filename.}

\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{tkinter}

\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{GoToCommand}\PYG{p}{:}

        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{x}

    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} when a command is converted to a string. The string}

    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{draw}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}

            \PYG{n}{cmd} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{BeginFillCommand}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{fillColor}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{draw}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{p}{)}
            
        \PYG{n}{beginFillButton} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Button}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{sideBar}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{text} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Begin Fill}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{command}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{beginFillHandler}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{penDownHandler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}

        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Here is another event handler. This one handles mouse clicks on the screen.}
        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{clickHandler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:} 
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} When a mouse click occurs, get the widthSize entry value and set the width of the }
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} pen to the widthSize value. The float(widthSize.get()) is needed because}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} the width is an integer, but the entry widget stores it as a string.}
            \PYG{n}{cmd} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{GoToCommand}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nb}{float}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{widthSize}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{penColor}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{draw}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{p}{)}          
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{listen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
           
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Here is how we tie the clickHandler to mouse clicks.}
        \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{onclick}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{clickHandler}\PYG{p}{)}  
        
        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{dragHandler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{cmd} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{GoToCommand}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n+nb}{float}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{widthSize}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{penColor}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{draw}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{p}{)}  
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{listen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            
        \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ondrag}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{dragHandler}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} the undoHandler undoes the last command by removing it from the }
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} sequence and then redrawing the entire picture. }
        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{undoHandler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{removeLast}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{clear}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{penup}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pendown}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{cmd} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{graphicsCommands}\PYG{p}{:}
                    \PYG{n}{cmd}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{draw}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{listen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                
        \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{onkeypress}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{undoHandler}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{u}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{listen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
   
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The main function in our GUI program is very simple. It creates the }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} root window. Then it creates the DrawingApplication frame which creates }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} all the widgets and has the logic for the event handlers. Calling mainloop}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} on the frames makes it start listening for events. The mainloop function will }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} return when the application is exited. }
\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{root} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Tk}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}  
    \PYG{n}{drawingApp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{DrawingApplication}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{root}\PYG{p}{)}  

    \PYG{n}{drawingApp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{mainloop}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Program Execution Completed.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
        
\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nv+vm}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}name\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}main\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\chapter{Computational Complexity}
\label{\detokenize{chap2/chap2:computational-complexity}}\label{\detokenize{chap2/chap2:chap2}}\label{\detokenize{chap2/chap2::doc}}
In the last chapter we developed a drawing program. To hold the drawing commands we built the \sphinxstyleemphasis{PyList} container class which is a lot like the built\sphinxhyphen{}in Python list class, but helps illustrate our first data structure. When we added a drawing command to the sequence we called the append method. It turns out that this method is called a lot. In fact, the flower picture in the first chapter took around 700 commands to draw. You can imagine that a complex picture with lots of free\sphinxhyphen{}hand drawing could contain thousands of drawing commands. When creating a free\sphinxhyphen{}hand drawing we want to append the next drawing command to the sequence quickly because there are so many commands being appended. How long does it take to append a drawing command to the sequence? Can we make a guess? Should we care about the exact amount of time?

In this chapter you’ll learn how to answer these questions and you’ll learn what questions are important for you as a computer programmer. First you’ll read about some principles of computer architecture to understand something about how long it takes a computer to do some simple operations. With that knowledge you’ll have the tools you’ll need to make informed decisions about how much time it might take to execute some code you have written.


\section{The PlotData Program}
\label{\detokenize{chap2/chap2:the-plotdata-program}}
You can \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{download}} the program by clicking here. This program is used to plot data written in the plot XML format presented in the text. The next program, the list timing access program, writes data in the plot XML format.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{turtle}
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{tkinter}
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{tkinter}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{colorchooser}
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{tkinter}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{filedialog}

\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{sys}

        \PYG{n+nb}{super}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n+nf+fm}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}init\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{master}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{datafile} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{datafile}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pack}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{buildWindow}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

 
    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{buildWindow}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
         
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{master}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{title}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Plot}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{n}{bar} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Menu}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{master}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{fileMenu} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Menu}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{bar}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{tearoff}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{n}{fileMenu}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{add\PYGZus{}command}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{label}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Load Plot Data...}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{command}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{loadFile}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{n}{fileMenu}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{add\PYGZus{}command}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{label}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Exit}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{command}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{master}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{quit}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{n}{bar}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{add\PYGZus{}cascade}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{label}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{File}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{menu}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{fileMenu}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{master}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{config}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{menu}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{bar}\PYG{p}{)}    
        
        \PYG{n}{canvas} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Canvas}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{width}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{height}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{800}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{canvas}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pack}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{side}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{LEFT}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{n}{theTurtle} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{RawTurtle}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{canvas}\PYG{p}{)}
         
        \PYG{n}{screen} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{getscreen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{tracer}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{datafile} \PYG{o}{!=} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{loadFile}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{datafile}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{strip}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n}{root} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Tk}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{datafile} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{None}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{sys}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{argv}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{datafile} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sys}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{argv}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}
    \PYG{n}{plotApp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{PlotApplication}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{root}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{datafile}\PYG{p}{)}  

    \PYG{n}{plotApp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{mainloop}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Program Execution Completed.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\section{List Access Timing}
\label{\detokenize{chap2/chap2:list-access-timing}}\label{\detokenize{chap2/chap2:listaccess}}
You can \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{download}}  the program by clicking here.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{datetime} 
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{random}
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{time}
        
\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Write an XML file with the results}
    \PYG{n}{file} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{ListAccessTiming.xml}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{w}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}?xml version=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{1.0}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ encoding=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{UTF\PYGZhy{}8}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ standalone=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{no}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ ?\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}Plot title=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Average List Element Access Time}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Test lists of size 1000 to 200000. }
    \PYG{n}{xmin} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}
    \PYG{n}{xmax} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{200000}
    
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Record the list sizes in xList and the average access time within}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} a list that size in yList for 1000 retrievals. }
    \PYG{n}{xList} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}
    \PYG{n}{yList} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}
    
    \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{xmin}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{xmax}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}

        \PYG{n}{xList}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{n}{prod} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}
        
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Creates a list of size x with all 0\PYGZsq{}s}
        \PYG{n}{lst} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{x}
        
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} let any garbage collection/memory allocation complete or at least}
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} settle down}
        \PYG{n}{time}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sleep}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Time before the 1000 test retrievals}
        \PYG{n}{starttime} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{datetime}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{datetime}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{now}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{v} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Find a random location within the list}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} and retrieve a value. Do a dummy operation}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} with that value to ensure it is really retrieved. }
            \PYG{n}{index} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{random}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{randint}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{val} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{]}
            \PYG{n}{prod} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{prod} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{val}
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Time after the 1000 test retrievals  }
        \PYG{n}{endtime} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{datetime}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{datetime}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{now}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The difference in time between start and end.}
        \PYG{n}{deltaT} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{endtime} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{starttime}
        
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Divide by 1000 for the average access time}
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} But also multiply by 1000000 for microseconds.}
        \PYG{n}{accessTime} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{deltaT}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{total\PYGZus{}seconds}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}
        
        \PYG{n}{yList}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{accessTime}\PYG{p}{)}
     
    \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{  \PYGZlt{}Axes\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{    \PYGZlt{}XAxis min=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n+nb}{str}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{xmin}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ max=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n+nb}{str}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{xmax}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZgt{}List Size\PYGZlt{}/XAxis\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{    \PYGZlt{}YAxis min=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n+nb}{str}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{min}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{yList}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ max=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n+nb}{str}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{60}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZgt{}Microseconds\PYGZlt{}/YAxis\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{  \PYGZlt{}/Axes\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{  \PYGZlt{}Sequence title=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Average Access Time vs List Size}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ color=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{red}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}   
    
    \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{xList}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}   
        \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{    \PYGZlt{}DataPoint x=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n+nb}{str}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{xList}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ y=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n+nb}{str}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{yList}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{/\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}    
        
    \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{  \PYGZlt{}/Sequence\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} This part of the program tests access at 100 random locations within a list}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} of 200,000 elements to see that all the locations can be accessed in }
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} about the same amount of time.}
    \PYG{n}{xList} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lst}
    \PYG{n}{yList} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{200000}
    
    \PYG{n}{time}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sleep}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{starttime} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{datetime}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{datetime}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{now}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{index} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{random}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{randint}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{200000}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{xList}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{xList}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
        \PYG{n}{endtime} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{datetime}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{datetime}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{now}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{deltaT} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{endtime} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{starttime}   
        \PYG{n}{yList}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{yList}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{index}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{deltaT}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{total\PYGZus{}seconds}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1000000}
        
    \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{  \PYGZlt{}Sequence title=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Access Time Distribution}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ color=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{blue}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}           
  
    \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{xList}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{xList}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{    \PYGZlt{}DataPoint x=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n+nb}{str}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ y=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n+nb}{str}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{yList}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{xList}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{/\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}    
        
    \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{  \PYGZlt{}/Sequence\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\section{The PyList Datatype}
\label{\detokenize{chap2/chap2:the-pylist-datatype}}\label{\detokenize{chap2/chap2:pylist}}
This is the chapter 2 version of this datatype. In chapter 4 another, more complete version of this datatype is described. You can \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{download the chapter 2 version of the datatype}} by clicking here.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{PyList}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The size below is an initial number of locations for the list object. The}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} count instance variable keeps track of how many elements are currently stored}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} in the list since self.items may have empty locations at the end.}
    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf+fm}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}init\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{size}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{items} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{size}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{count} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}

    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{item}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{count} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{items}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} We must make the list bigger by allocating a new list and copying}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} all the elements over to the new list.}
            \PYG{n}{newitems} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{count} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
            \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{k} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{items}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n}{newitems}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{k}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{items}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{k}\PYG{p}{]}

            \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{items} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{newitems}
            
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{items}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{count}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{item}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{count} \PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}

\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{p} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{PyList}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{k} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{p}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{k}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{p}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{items}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{p}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{count}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{p}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{items}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nv+vm}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}name\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}main\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\chapter{Recursion}
\label{\detokenize{chap3/chap3:recursion}}\label{\detokenize{chap3/chap3::doc}}
Don’t think too hard! That’s one of the central themes of this chapter. It’s not often that you tell computer programmers not to think too hard, but this is one time when it is appropriate. You need to read this chapter if you have not written recursive functions before. Most computer science students start by learning to program in a style called \sphinxstyleemphasis{imperative} programming. This simply means that you are likely used to thinking about creating variables, storing values, and updating those values as a program proceeds. In this chapter you are going to begin learning a different style of programming called \sphinxstyleemphasis{functional} programming. When you program in the functional style, you think much more about the definition of \sphinxstyleemphasis{what} you are programming than \sphinxstyleemphasis{how} you are going to program it. Some say that writing recursive functions is a \sphinxstyleemphasis{declarative} approach rather than an \sphinxstyleemphasis{imperative} approach. You’ll start to learn what that means for you very soon. When you start to get good at writing recursive functions you’ll be surprised how easy it can be!


\section{Scope}
\label{\detokenize{chap3/chap3:scope}}
You can \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{download the program}} by clicking here.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{math}


\PYG{n}{PI} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{math}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}

\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{area}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{radius}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{global} \PYG{n}{z}
    \PYG{n}{z} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{6}
    \PYG{n}{theArea} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{PI} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{radius} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
    
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{theArea}


\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{global} \PYG{n}{z}
    
    \PYG{n}{historyOfPrompts} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}
    \PYG{n}{historyOfOutput} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}
    
    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{getInput}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{prompt}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{input}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{prompt}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{historyOfPrompts}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{prompt}\PYG{p}{)}
        
        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{x}
    
    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{showOutput}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{val}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{historyOfOutput}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{val}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{val}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{n}{rString} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{getInput}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Please enter the radius of a circle: }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{n}{r} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{float}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{rString}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{n}{val} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{area}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{r}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{z}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{showOutput}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{The area of the circle is }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nb}{str}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{val}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
    
\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nv+vm}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}name\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}main\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\section{Recursive Spiral}
\label{\detokenize{chap3/chap3:recursive-spiral}}\label{\detokenize{chap3/chap3:recursivespiral}}
You can \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{download the program}} by clicking here.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{turtle}

\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{drawSpiral}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{length}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{colorBase}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}color is a 24 bit value that is changing a bit}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}each time for a nice color effect}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{length} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{k}{return}
    
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} add 2\PYGZca{}10 to the old color modulo 2\PYGZca{}24 }
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} the modulo 2\PYGZca{}24 prevents the color from }
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} getting too big.}
    \PYG{n}{newcolor} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{16}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{\PYGZpc{}}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{24}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} find the color base integer value}
    \PYG{n}{base} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{colorBase}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{16}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} now if the new color is less than the base}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} add the base module 2\PYGZca{}24.}
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{newcolor} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{n}{base}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{newcolor} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{newcolor} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{base}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{\PYGZpc{}}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{24}\PYG{p}{)}
     
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} let newcolor be the hex string after conversion.   }
    \PYG{n}{newcolor} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{hex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{newcolor}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{]}
    
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} add a pound sign and zeroes to the front so it}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} is 6 characters long plus the pound sign for a}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} proper color string. }
    \PYG{n}{newcolor} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZsh{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{0}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{6}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{newcolor}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n}{newcolor}

    \PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{newcolor}\PYG{p}{)}   
    \PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{forward}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{length}\PYG{p}{)}   
    \PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{left}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{90}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{n}{drawSpiral}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{length}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{newcolor}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{colorBase}\PYG{p}{)}
        
\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{t} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Turtle}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{screen} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{getscreen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{speed}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{penup}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pendown}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n}{drawSpiral}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{200}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZsh{}000000}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZsh{}ff00ff}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    
    \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{exitonclick}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
    

\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nv+vm}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}name\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}main\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Sunflower Program}
\label{\detokenize{chap3/chap3:sunflower-program}}
You can \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{download the program}} by clicking here.

This program is not included in the text, but is a good program to look at when starting chapter 3. It illustrates the golden rule and the
fibonacci sequence. Computing fibonacci numbers both recursively and iteratively can lead to a good discussion of computational complexity as well as recursion. You can write a program to time computing fibonacci numbers both recursively and iteratively. The recursive version will not handle numbers bigger than 20 or so. The iterative version can go very high. It is interesting to look at the graph of these two methods of computing fibonacci numbers as a contrast in what is efficient and what is not.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{} }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    Author: Kent D. Lee}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    Date: 9/26/2014}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    Copyright (c) 2014}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    Free for educational use. Others may use with permission.}

\PYG{l+s+sd}{    Source: }

\PYG{l+s+sd}{    I used http://fractalfoundation.org/OFC/OFC\PYGZhy{}11\PYGZhy{}3.html as a source for this }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    information. }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    Description:}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    This program draws sunflower seeds in the pattern of a funflower. The ration of }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    consecutive fibonacci numbers in the sequence approach the golden ratio as the }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    sequence grows. In the limit, the ratio of two consecutive fibonacci numbers is}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    the golden ratio. }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    In the sunflower fibonacci numbers can be observed by counting the number of seeds}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    in the spiral arms. Count the number of seeds in a left spiral arm and a right spiral}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    arm. You\PYGZsq{}ll see that they are two fibonacci numbers. }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    You may have to make the radius size of the seeds constant to count the seeds. It won\PYGZsq{}t}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    look as pretty, but will be easier to count. You may also need to increase the forward }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{    to separate the seeds. }
\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}}

\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{turtle}
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{math}


\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{Circle}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf+fm}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}init\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{radius}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{width}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{white}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{outline}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{black}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{radius} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{radius}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{width} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{width}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{color}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{outline} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{outline}
        
    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{draw}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{centerX} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{xcor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{centerY} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ycor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{penup}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{centerX}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{radius}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{centerY}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pendown}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{width}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{width}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pencolor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{outline}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fillcolor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{turtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{begin\PYGZus{}fill}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{361}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{newX} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{radius} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{math}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{cos}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mf}{180.0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{math}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{centerX}

\chapter{Sequences}
\label{\detokenize{chap4/chap4:sequences}}\label{\detokenize{chap4/chap4:chap4}}\label{\detokenize{chap4/chap4::doc}}
Computers are really good at dealing with large amounts of information. They can repeat a task over and over again without getting bored. When they repeat a task they are generally doing the same thing to similar data or objects. It is natural to want to organize those objects into some kind of structure so that our program can easily switch from one object to the next. How objects are added to a sequence or collection and how we move from one item to the next has some impact on how we might want to organize the collection of data in a program.

In this chapter we look at different ways of organizing data into a sequence. We’ll also examine how to use Python to make working with sequences convenient. Operator overloading in Python lets us build sequences that we can manipulate with intuitive operations. Finally, we also examine how the organization of a sequence affects the computation complexity of operations on it.


\section{The PyList Datatype}
\label{\detokenize{chap4/chap4:the-pylist-datatype}}\label{\detokenize{chap4/chap4:ch4pylist}}

\section{The Sort Animation}
\label{\detokenize{chap4/chap4:the-sort-animation}}

            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Why twice? Because once doesn\PYGZsq{}t seem to display}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} the line the first time through for some reason            }
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{red}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pendown}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{pivot}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ycor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
            \PYG{n}{j} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}

            \PYG{k}{while} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{k}{while} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{j} \PYG{o+ow}{and} \PYG{o+ow}{not} \PYG{n}{pivot} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}
                    \PYG{n}{i}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
                \PYG{k}{while} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{j} \PYG{o+ow}{and} \PYG{n}{pivot} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}
                    \PYG{n}{j}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}

                \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{:}
                    \PYG{n}{tmp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}
                    \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}
                    \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ycor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
                    \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{tmp}
                    \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ycor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
                    \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                    \PYG{n}{i}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
                    \PYG{n}{j}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}

            \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{pivotIndex}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}
            \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{pivotIndex}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{pivotIndex}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{pivotIndex}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ycor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{pivot}
            \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ycor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{green}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{white}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}   

            \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{j}


        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{quicksortRecursively}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}

                \PYG{k}{return} 

            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{stopping}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{k}{return}

            \PYG{n}{pivotIndex} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{partition}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{stopping}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{k}{return}

            \PYG{n}{quicksortRecursively}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{pivotIndex}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{stopping}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{k}{return}

            \PYG{n}{quicksortRecursively}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{pivotIndex}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{merge}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{mid}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{length} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{stop} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{start}
            \PYG{n}{log} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{math}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{log}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{length}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{blue}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{penup}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{log}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pendown}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{forward}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{length}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n}{lst} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}
            \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{start}
            \PYG{n}{j} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{mid}

            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Merge the two lists while each has more elements}
            \PYG{k}{while} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{n}{mid} \PYG{o+ow}{and} \PYG{n}{j} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}
                    \PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
                    \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ycor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
                    \PYG{n}{i}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
                \PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
                    \PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
                    \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ycor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
                    \PYG{n}{j}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
                \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}screen.update()}

            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Copy in the rest of the start to mid sequence    }
            \PYG{k}{while} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{n}{mid}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ycor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{i}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
                \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}screen.update()}

            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Copy in the rest of the mid to stop sequence}
            \PYG{k}{while} \PYG{n}{j} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{n}{mid}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{j}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ycor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{j}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
                \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}screen.update()}

            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Copy the elements back to the original sequence   }
            \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{start}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}
                \PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{start}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ycor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{green}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{mergeSortRecursively}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} We must use \PYGZgt{}= here only when the sequence we are sorting}

            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{start} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{k}{return} 

            \PYG{n}{mid} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{start} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}

            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{stopping}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{k}{return}

            \PYG{n}{length} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{start}
            \PYG{n}{log} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{math}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{log}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{length}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{red}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{penup}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{log}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pendown}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{forward}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{length}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Why twice? Because once doesn\PYGZsq{}t seem to display}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} the line the first time through for some reason}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{red}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{penup}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{log}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pendown}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{theTurtle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{forward}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{length}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{update}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}  

            \PYG{n}{mergeSortRecursively}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{mid}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{stopping}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{k}{return}            

            \PYG{n}{mergeSortRecursively}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{mid}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{stop}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{stopping}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}

        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{select}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{minIndex} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{start}
            \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{minIndex}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{green}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{start}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{minIndex}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}
                    \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{minIndex}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{black}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
                    \PYG{n}{minIndex} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{i}
                    \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{minIndex}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{green}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

            \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{minIndex}

        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{selectionSort}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n}{minIndex} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{select}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{stopping}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
                    \PYG{k}{return}
                \PYG{n}{tmp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{seq}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{]}

        \PYG{n}{screen}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{listen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The main function in our GUI program is very simple. It creates the }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} root window. Then it creates the SortAnimation frame which creates }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} all the widgets and has the logic for the event handlers. Calling mainloop}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} on the frames makes it start listening for events. The mainloop function will }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} return when the application is exited. }
\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{root} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Tk}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}  
    \PYG{n}{anim} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{SortAnimation}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{root}\PYG{p}{)}  

    \PYG{n}{anim}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{mainloop}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nv+vm}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}name\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}main\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{main}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{k}{pass}
    
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} In the X and O classes below the constructor begins by initializing the }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} RawTurtle part of the object with the call to super().\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}init\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}(canvas). The}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} super() call returns the class of the superclass (the class above the X or O}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} in the class hierarchy). In this case, the superclass is RawTurtle. Then, }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} calling \PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}init\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{} on the superclass initializes the part of the object that is}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} a RawTurtle. }

        \PYG{n+nb}{super}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n+nf+fm}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}init\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{canvas}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ht}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{shape}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{circle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{goto}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{)}
        
    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{eval}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{Human}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The minimax function is given a player (1 = Computer, \PYGZhy{}1 = Human) and a}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} board object. When the player = Computer, minimax returns the maximum }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} value of all possible moves that the Computer could make. When the player =}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Human then minimax returns the minimum value of all possible moves the Human}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} could make. Minimax works by assuming that at each move the Computer will pick}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} its best move and the Human will pick its best move. It does this by making a }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} move for the player whose turn it is, and then recursively calling minimax. }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The base case results when, given the state of the board, someone has won or }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} the board is full.    }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} READER EXERCISE: YOU MUST COMPLETE THIS FUNCTION}
\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{minimax}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{player}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{board}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{pass}

        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{computerTurn}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The locked variable prevents another event from being }
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} processed while the computer is making up its mind. }
            \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{locked} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{True}
	    
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Call Minimax to find the best move to make.}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} READER EXERCISE: YOU MUST COMPLETE THIS CODE}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} After writing this code, the maxMove tuple should}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} contain the best move for the computer. For instance,}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} if the best move is in the first row and third column}
            \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} then maxMove would be (0,2).}
	    
            \PYG{n}{row}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{col} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{maxMove}
            \PYG{n}{board}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{row}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{col}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{X}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cv}\PYG{p}{)}
            \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{locked} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
    
      
        \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{mouseClick}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{o+ow}{not} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{locked}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n}{row} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{y} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{)}
                \PYG{n}{col} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{)}
    
                \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{board}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{row}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{col}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{eval}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{:}
                    \PYG{n}{board}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{row}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{col}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{O}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cv}\PYG{p}{)} 
                    
                    \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turn} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Computer}
                    
                    \PYG{n}{board}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{drawXOs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                    
                    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{o+ow}{not} \PYG{n}{board}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{full}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o+ow}{and} \PYG{o+ow}{not} \PYG{n+nb}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{board}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{eval}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{:}
                        \PYG{n}{computerTurn}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                    
                        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{turn} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Human}
                        
                        \PYG{n}{board}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{drawXOs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
                    \PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
                        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{locked} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k+kc}{True}
                        
                    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{board}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{eval}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{:}
                        \PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{messagebox}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{showwarning}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Game Over}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{X wins!!!}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
          
                    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{board}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{eval}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{:}
                        \PYG{n}{tkinter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{messagebox}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{showwarning}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Game Over}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{O wins. \section{The Linked List Datatype}
\label{\detokenize{chap4/chap4:the-linked-list-datatype}}
You can \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{download}} the code for the linked list datatype by clicking here.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{LinkedList}\PYG{p}{:}
    
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The \PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}Node class is used internally by the LinkedList class. It is }
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} invisible from outside this class due to the two underscores}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} that precede the class name. Python mangles names so that they}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} are not recognizable outside the class when two underscores}

    \PYG{n}{lst4} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LinkedList}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{lst4}
    
    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{lst} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n}{lst4}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Test 9 Passed}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Test 9 Failed}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
        
    \PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{insert}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{333}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{lst4}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{333}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{lst} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n}{lst4}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Test 10 Passed}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Test 10 Failed}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}  
        
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lst}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lst4}\PYG{p}{)}
    
\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nv+vm}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}name\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}main\PYGZus{}\PYGZus{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}

\section{The Stack Datatype}
